description: From Middle English morwenyng, from morwen +‎ -ing. By surface analysis, morn +‎ ing. See also morrow (Middle English morwe).

entries.meaning: The early part of the day, especially from dawn to noon. [from 13th c.]
examples: I'm working in the morning, so let's meet in the afternoon.

entries.meaning: (figurative) The early part of anything. [from 16th c.]
(obsolete) That part of the day from dawn until the main meal (typically in late afternoon). [18th–19th c.]
examples: Celestina  […]  retired to her own room, leaving her friend to the pleasing and important occupation of the toilet, in which half of what is now called morning, was usually passed by Matilda.

entries.meaning: (chiefly Scotland) The first alcoholic drink of the day; a morning draught. [from 18th c.]
